Article title: Spokesman of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office of the State Council Made a Statement on the Violent Incident of Storming the Legislative Council in Hong Kong

Article text: On 2 July, the Spokesman of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office of the State Council issued a statement regarding the violent storm at the Legislative Council of the Hong Kong SAR, expressing his firm support to the HKSAR Government and the police in handling the incident in accordance with the law, and investigating the perpetrators of the violence and holding them criminally responsible in accordance with the law.

The spokesman said that on July 1, the day when people from all walks of life in Hong Kong commemorated Hong Kong's return to the motherland and the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, some extremist radicals stormed the Legislative Council building in an extremely violent manner and deliberately damaged the Legislative Council's facilities under the pretext of opposing the review of the law by the SAR government. Such serious offences trample on Hong Kong's rule of law, destroy Hong Kong's social order, damage Hong Kong's fundamental interests, and are a blatant challenge to the principle of "one country, two systems".

The spokesman said that the Central Government resolutely supports the HKSAR Government and the police in discharging their responsibilities in accordance with the law, and supports the respective HKSAR authorities in prosecuting the criminal responsibility of the perpetrators of violence in accordance with the law, in order to restore the normal social order of the society as soon as possible, protect the personal safety and property of the citizens, and maintain the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong.

Article title: Chief Executive of Hong Kong SAR, Carrie Lam, Strongly Condemns the Violent Attack and Destruction of the Legislative Council.

Article text: In the early hours of 2 July, the Hong Kong Chief Executive, Carrie Lam, said that she felt strong resentment and sadness at the extremely violent way in which some protesters stormed the Legislative Council on 1 July and that she strongly condemned it. The Hong Kong SAR government will undoubtedly prosecute any illegal act to the end.

Some radicals in Hong Kong violently stormed and occupied the Legislative Council on the evening of the July 1st, and completely recklessly smashed wreaked havoc on the facilities in the Legislative Council chamber. Hong Kong police moved in and cleared the area after midnight, driving out the protesters who had violently stormed and occupied the LegCo building. 

During a media briefing around 4 am on July 2, Carrie Lam said that some protesters had been confronting police since the morning of the 1st, blocking roads and attacking police officers with unknown liquids. At noon, the situation took a sharp turn for the worse, with protesters storming the Legislative Council building in an extremely violent manner, using iron bars and shopping carts to smash the glass facade, and bringing toxic chemical powder to attack police. In the evening, the protesters entered the Legislative Council building and recklessly trashed it, destroying the highly revered Chamber and the Hong Kong SAR emblem.

Carrie Lam said that these lawless acts of violence have seriously disrupted the core value of the rule of law in Hong Kong. She was outraged and saddened by this, and strongly condemned it, and believed that the public shared these feelings.

She said the police had shown restraint in dealing with the violence throughout the day, but any violations of the law will definitely be pursued to the end.

They all express strong condemnation of the violence, support for the Hong Kong SAR government and police in handling the incident, and the need to uphold the rule of law and maintain social order in Hong Kong. Article title: Hong Kong public opinion condemns the violent storming of the Legislative Council and calls for strict punishment of these atrocities to uphold the rule of law.

Article text: On the 22nd anniversary of Hong Kong's return to the motherland, some extremists stormed the Legislative Council building in an extremely violent manner and created havoc. Hong Kong's media unanimously condemned this on 2 July, saying that the violence seriously violated the rule of law in Hong Kong, which is incompatible with the general harmonious development of society, and contrary to the general public's vision of living and working in peace and contentment. The media called for strict punishment of the thugs without tolerance, to reshape the environment of the rule of law and restore a peaceful environment to the people of Hong Kong.

An editorial in Ta Kung Pao newspaper states that the so-called "peaceful and rational" movement, in close collaboration with trouble-making local politicians and foreign powers, has continuously incited riots, thereby now revealing its true nature as a "bloody and violent" anti-government movement.
The editorial pointed out that these atrocities are essentially an attack on the vital interests of the people of Hong Kong. The editorial called on all Hong Kong citizens to stand together and give the police full support to enforce the law to punish the thugs severely and not tolerate them, and to expose the malign agents (“black hands”) who manipulate from behind the scenes, in order to prevent future troubles.

The Hong Kong Commercial Daily newspaper pointed out that the demonstration had turned into a violent and extreme attack, which has damaged public facilities, and security and stability. Furthermore, the attack has damaged Hong Kong's core values and spirit, as well as Hong Kong's reputation and image in the international community.

An editorial in Sing Tao Daily newspaper stated that the majority of Hong Kong citizens yearn for peace and stability, and the behaviour of these violent extremists completely works against this wish. Faced with the trauma caused by the violence, all walks of life in Hong Kong should work together to curb this frenzy and bring society back on track. Members of Parliament, organizations from all sectors and the public must clearly say "no" to violence, and not let it worsen, especially among young people, so as to not exacerbate social unrest and damage Hong Kong’s future.

An editorial in Ming Pao newspaper is titled "Violence is violence", pointing out that "violence against the Legislative Council must be condemned most severely". According to the editorial, Hong Kong is still free and open, and the vast majority of Hong Kong people are peaceful, rational and non-violent. The whole society must stand up and draw a clear line against violence, and must not take a conciliatory attitude. If violence is tolerated, it will only continue to spread and become more serious.

Hong Kong public opinion generally believes that Hong Kong's achievements today are hard-won and are the result of the hard work and construction of all Hong Kong citizens. Violence should not be allowed to destroy Hong Kong's values, rule of law and order. They call on the whole society to put aside their differences and work together to protect Hong Kong's achievements and beauty, and work together to create a better future.
